head.title: Metro Business; E.P.A. Opposes Meadowlands Mall

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New Jersey

hedline.hl1: Metro Business; E.P.A. Opposes Meadowlands Mall

abstract.p: Environmental Protection Agency recommends that a permit be denied to Mills Corp to build retail mall in Carlstadt, NJ, because project would involve filling in hundreds of acres of Meadowlands wetlands (S)

block.p: The federal Environmental Protection Agency yesterday recommended that a permit be denied to the Mills Corporation of Arlington, Va., to build a retail mall on environmentally sensitive property in the New Jersey Meadowlands.

The E.P.A. based its recommendation to the Army Corps of Engineers, which has jurisdiction over the project, on regulations in the Clean Water Act requiring projects to have minimal environmental impact, said Mary Mears, a spokeswoman for the agency.

The federal Environmental Protection Agency yesterday recommended that a permit be denied to the Mills Corporation of Arlington, Va., to build a retail mall on environmentally sensitive property in the New Jersey Meadowlands.

The E.P.A. based its recommendation to the Army Corps of Engineers, which has jurisdiction over the project, on regulations in the Clean Water Act requiring projects to have minimal environmental impact, said Mary Mears, a spokeswoman for the agency.

Mills is seeking permission to build a 2.1-million-square-foot mall in Carlstadt, N.J., less than 10 miles west of Manhattan. The company has proposed five plans for the $1 billion project that would involve filling in 132 to 206 acres of wetlands. The E.P.A. recommended rejecting all five alternatives, even though the company had promised to recreate the wetlands elsewhere, Ms. Mears said. She said Mills had refused to consider dividing the mall project into separate sites, and that its proposals for recreating the wetlands was unacceptable.
Company officials could not be reached for comment.
